column4: It seems like one of my computer at home have changed IP address from my DHCP. I want to find out what the new IP number can be.
Am looking for a ping utility that can ping a subnet i specify. Please advice.
did you try ping?
Oh, can "normal" ping handle subnet as argument?
use the -b
but a firewall might stop a system from responding
ping -b <broadcast address>
I am on a different subnet that the computer I want to ping. Will it still work?
what are you really attempting to do?
do you administrate the DHCP server?
ping!!!  see above
ping. see above
What do you mean? I have runned "ping -b 192.168.2.255" without any good result
do you run the DHCP server?  Is the DHCP server a linux box or is it  your router?  or is it a DHCP server from your Internet Service PRovider?
what (physically) is the DHCP server?
Yes, I can login to the DHCP server and see what IP number that my stationary computer has. But I feel that writing a line in a prompt is far more faster.
you can set the DHCP server to always assign the same address to your computer.  Just assign by MAC address
does that make sense
I know, but that is NOT my question today!
OK, what is your objective and what is your question and what is your favorite color. ;)
Whatever. Found the program "nmap" that will do what am looking for. "nmap -sP 192.168.2.0/24"
Blue is a nice color :-)
